title: What is the best free MIDI player? - Quora

response.answer_text: In general, there isn’t a singular best MIDI player application; the vast majority of media player applications for desktop operating systems handle MIDI files the same. If your favorite music player app plays .mid files, then for you, that’s the best MIDI player. That said… at least for Windows, the built-in MIDI playback support that all of these programs use? It’s junk. It uses a severely compressed soundfont licensed from Roland; the original files were good, but Windows’ version isn’t worthwhile. I’d suggest installing VirtualMIDISynth and the related MIDI Mapper, along with a good soundfont like FluidR3, OmegaGMGS2, and/or Fatboy, and disabling the Windows-built-in synth in Device Manager.(Note that some applications occasionally have problems; right now, for me, Media Player Classic won’t work with VMS, though it has in the past. But Windows Media Player, which had problems in the past, works fine now. Winamp works too… if you still use that.)

That question doesn’t make any sense. MIDI is a method of communication between electronic instruments (hardware or software). There’s no such thing as sound in MIDI, only things like pitch, velocity, key pressure, note on/off etc.Sound is then generated by the instrument based on the MIDI parameters. So a MIDI “player” isn’t something that exists. You can feed MIDI to any instrument, depending on the sound you want. If your question is “what is the best free MIDI-compatible instrument” then that’s a whole different question, that doesn’t have any specific answer except “it depends what you want”. There are tons of very good free VST instruments, for any style, any use. Far to many to count, let alone define one as “best”. I do love Helm, it’s open-source and great.
